11:14 am
BE11:15am

Despite all of these factors, we might have maintained our OW rating if we still had
confidence in the company’s strategy. But we are concerned that as soon
as leverage comes down it will jump right back up when the next deal is
completed. As the company said last night, “Our decision… is to execute a
strategy on deleveraging faster so we can better position the company for
future consolidation.” And despite the company repeatedly citing its
“industry-high margins” yesterday, its EBIT margin has fallen from 27.2%
in 2015 to 23.2% in 2018 (and we model another 200+ bps decline in
2019). We no longer see a compelling upside case and thus downgrade to
Neutral.

St Andrean @Blank - and print newspapers are better for lighting fires than iPads
red @marktimesomeone always in the loop. or at least one person can be relied upon to spill and so it gets to some mkt participants. with so many moving parts, cant expect everyones morals to stay in check
1st Lt. Fletcher Christian I had some residual Marconi shares that I tried to sell. The broker couldn't execute the sale because the share value was less than the trade fee. They had to circumnavigate the computer and broker procedures to get the sale executed. :)
BE11:15am

As we delve into below, KHC’s EBITDA has not grown over the last five years (flat), its revenue has declined (shrunk), and its balance sheet has ballooned (levered). This is not an ideal progression of financial metrics.

BE11:15am

If we could sum up KHC’s issues in one stat it would be this: The
midpoint of 2019 EBITDA guidance ($6.4B) is below what KHC
printed on a pro-forma combined basis in 2014 ($6.5B). We thus
think it is more than fair to ask if any fundamental value for KHC has
been created since the Kraft Heinz merger. We also think that between
KHC’s and ABI’s struggles in recent years, it is reasonable to question
the entire 3G strategy. Investors for years have asked if 3G’s extreme
belt-tightening model ultimately would result in brand equity erosion.
We think the answer arguably came yesterday in the form of a $15B (!)
intangible asset write-down for the Kraft and Oscar Mayer brands.

BornCynic Who would have thought that a company selling stuff like "Velveeta cheese and Jell-O pudding" would have problems?

Any investor backing another acquisition must be on some kind of Brewster's Millions type bet. Here's Stifel.

11:20 am
BE11:20am

A weak earnings performance and outlook is no doubt concerning here, but we find
the reduction in the dividend as most concerning and was seemingly completely
disconnected from the business performance and outlook. The dividend is being
reduced by 36% as it moves down from $2.50 to $1.60 (annual rate) – still representing a
roughly 4.6% dividend yield at the lower rate and using our target price, but representing a
more sustainable rate for the future (grow in line with its EBITDA in 2020 and beyond). The
goal here – pay down debt more quickly to be able to undertake industry consolidation.

IMP.GLD Or Brunswick were involved in organising the press outreach, and as per they haven't got a clue.
marktime @BornCynic our first ISA gazillionaire?
BE11:20am

After this earnings rebase, Kraft Heinz will have invested a large chunk of its cost
savings back into the business and while this is creating a stronger, more sustainable
rate of revenue growth for the business, it is causing investors to question the
favorable economics of future acquisitions for the company and its ability to achieve
(and hold) the synergies.

BE11:21am

And Credit Suisse, who to give them credit were negative going in.

11:21 am
BE11:21am

This not your typical “reset the base and everything will be fine”
story. The dividend cut, the $15.8B write-down of the Kraft and Oscar Mayer
trademarks, and the guidance for further divestitures demonstrate the hallmarks
of a company that has a serious balance sheet problem. Net debt has gone up
not down over the past two years as pension plan payments, the unwinding of a
securitization program, and the high dividend payout more than sucked up the
cash flow. The company’s debt-equity ratio, which lenders find very important,
will increase significantly now that the asset write-downs have reduced the
denominator. We think this partly explains why the company had to guide to
higher interest expense in 2019 even though it is using proceeds from two
announced divestitures to pay down debt. It also pokes an enormous hole in
management’s contention that it can execute a meaningful acquisition any time
soon.

red good stuff that cathedral cheese, hope new owners dont cost cut the flavour out

BE11:30am

Dairy Crest Group (‘Dairy Crest’), the producer of leading British food brands including
Cathedral City, Clover, Country Life and Frylight, and value added ingredients, has today
(22nd February 2019) announced that it has reached an agreement for a recommended cash
offer for the Group's entire share capital from Saputo Dairy UK, a newly formed company
that is part of Saputo Inc.
The recommended offer is at 620p per ordinary Dairy Crest share, leading to an
implied market capitalisation of £976m. The Directors of Dairy Crest have been advised by
Greenhill that the terms of the offer are 'fair and reasonable'. The proposed offer represents
a premium to the closing price on the 20th February 2019 of approximately 11.7%, noting the
recent appreciation of the Group's share price. On a thirty day basis the share price premium
is approximately 27.1% whilst on a 90 day measure it is approximately 33.8%.
The acquirer is a top-ten global diary group - Based in Canada and listed on the Toronto
Stock Exchange, Saputo Inc., is one of the world's top ten dairy groups, producing,
marketing and distributing a wide array of products with extensive activities in Argentina
(No.2 market position), Australia (No.1), Canada (No.1) and the USA, where it has a No.3
share in cheese. The Group owns and markets a wide number of proprietary brands,
operates from 62 plants in 40+ countries and recorded, for the nine months ended 31st
December 2018, consolidated revenues of approximately CDN$10,265 million (£5,964
million) and net earnings of CDN$631 million (£367 million).

Tom Dalgleish Always frsutrating when somebody takes a shine to an otherwise basket case

The offer
values DCG's equity at £975m and represents an FY19 exit EBITDA/PER multiple of
13.1x/17.5x on JEF forecasts. It also represents a 30% premium to what we view
as DCG's undisturbed share price of 476p on 15 February 2019. We view 13x as
a robust multiple for a UK foods business in the light of precedent transactions
such as Weetabix (11.8x), United Biscuits (10.5x) and Iglo (8.5x). However, some
shareholders may reference the greater than 600p share price prevailing during the middle of
2017 (for the record JEF had an Underperform rating on DCG at the time.)

BE11:46am

Citi View. We view PFG’s main future challenges as: i) lack of profitability in its
home credit division, with insufficient revenue to offset the costs of its employed
workforce, and constraints on PFG’s ability to incentivize its CEMs to collect on
outstanding loans; ii) slower growth in the credit card business Vanquis, due to the
loss of distribution channels, increased affordability checks slowing new customer
growth and higher minimum payments reducing growth in outstanding balances; iii)
higher impairment at Vanquis due to forbearance measures and the loss of ROP.
NSF proposes significant cost reductions. Given time, we believe PFG had the
potential to achieve the home credit cost reductions itself. But central and borrowing
cost reductions are additive. The potential for revenue synergies between Vanquis,
Everyday Loans and NSF Guarantor Loans Division looks compelling, and shorter
term crystallization of value in Moneybarn and Satsuma looks attractive.
Our initial reaction is that NSF / PFG could offer better returns, more quickly, than
PFG could achieve standalone. However, we see FCA approval of NSF proposals
as key. e.g. NSF intends to reintroduce ROP at Vanquis, reduce the length of home
credit loans and introduce a more flexible operating model including a variable pay
structure and flexible working hours for CEMs. These are measures we believe
PFG would have loved to implement itself, but has so far been unable to do so.

11:58 am
BE11:58am

A time to revisit UK video gaming: Sentiment in the global video game industry
has been weak of late after a number of setbacks in 2018. Namely, China delayed
game approvals and Fortnite’s large player base continued to act as a headwind for
new title user growth. This ultimately led to a number of AAA publishers cutting
their guidance. While this ripple of negativity understandably also weighed on UK
video game companies, the reality is that most were well insulated from these
trends given their geographic positioning and niche games and/or audiences. In
fact, almost all upgraded their revenue and profit estimates in this period. With
some industry headwinds subsiding and UK valuations still 25% lower from highs,
we believe this is an opportune time to revisit some of these names. This note
provides updates on each company, but we highlight our upgrade to Buy on
Codemasters as a near-term opportunity given its significant valuation discount
and the upside potential after its recent development deal with NetEase.
● Codemasters: While we admire Codemasters’ strong IP and dominant market
position in AAA racing games, we were more cautious about the outlook in
summer 2018 given ONRUSH’s underperformance. However, this view needs to
change as the company’s IP has provided a more resilient financial performance
than we had expected. This, combined with a strong pipeline for next year and
meaningful potential upgrades from the signing of a development agreement with
NetEase, means there is a pathway to significant returns in the stock over the next
year. We upgrade Codemasters to Buy and believe the c30% valuation gap to peers
is undeserved.
● Frontier Developments: While the company almost doubled revenues in H1 2019,
the news that its fourth franchise will be released in H1 2020E and a large paid-for
Elite Dangerous extension is expected in FY 2020 was the focus. With at least one
major release now scheduled pa from FY 2020 onwards and competition driving
down game distribution fees, the growth and margin outlook is positive.
● Team17: On a multi-year view, Team17 has very strong prospects as it continues to
launch close to 10 new titles pa and builds its back catalogue. 2019 is likely to be a
year when the company looks to pursue M&A, either from its label partners (which
could quickly internalise margin) or to bring a new external franchise to the group.
With launches in China in 2019 also a possibility, we look forward to another year
of progress for the company.

BE11:59am

Sumo: Sumo has a higher degree of revenue visibility given its co-development model than many appreciate. We believe it currently has c85% of budgeted development fees contracted for 2019E. Utilisation rates can thus be modelled and margins managed. While this does alleviate the big upside potential in a given year, it also reduces risk in many ways. With strong visibility, Sumo is likely to move the dial through M&A in 2019. Should the company spend its cash pile this year, we believe this could drive annualised upgrades of c20%.

BE11:59am

● Keywords Studios: With the industry headwinds in 2018 rolling off and new
tailwinds emerging, our confidence in Keywords’ organic outlook has certainly
improved. Furthermore, given its healthy balance sheet, we believe non-equity
funded M&A will continue to be a driver of earnings over the coming year.
● Valuation: The global video game sector trades on 22.5x 2019E P/E versus UKlisted gaming stocks on c20.5x, representing a c10% discount. We make a number
of price target changes to reflect peer multiple contractions in the past few months
and adjust our estimates, but we retain our positive stance on the industry
